elements.content: The observation of a reversible chemical transformation corresponding to an external stimulus in the solid state is intriguing in the exploration of smart materials, which can potentially be applied in molecular machines, molecular switches, sensors, and data storage devices. The solid-state photodimerization reaction of 1,3-bis­[2-(4-pyridyl)­ethenyl]­benzene (1,3-bpeb) in a one-dimensional coordination polymer {[Cd2(1,3-bpeb)2­(4-FBA)4]·H2O} n (4-FBA = 4-fluorobenzoate) with 365 nm UV light afforded syn-tetrakis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2,9,10-diethano­[2.2]­metacyclophane (syn-tpmcp) in quantitative yield via a single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformation. Upon irradiation with 254 nm UV light, an SCSC conversion from syn-tpmcp to 1,3-bpeb was also achieved in quantitative yield within the syn-tpmcp-supported coordination polymer {[Cd2(syn-tpmcp)­(4-FBA)4]·H2O} n . In particular, accompanied by the reversible transformation between 1,3-bpeb and syn-tpmcp, the coordination chain exhibits photocontrollable fluorescence-switching behavior, which makes this intelligent material an appealing candidate for practical applications.

elements.content: Reversible single-crystal-to-single-crystal photodimerization and dedimerization reaction between 1,3-bis­[2-(4-pyridyl)­ethenyl]­benzene in a 1D coordination polymer {[Cd2(1,3-bpeb)2­(4-FBA)4]·H2O} n and syn-tetrakis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2,9,10-diethano­[2.2]­metacyclophane in a 1D coordination polymer {[Cd2(syn-tpmcp)­(4-FBA)4]·H2O} n proceeded readily under irradiation with UV light of different wavelengths. Accompanied by such a reversible process, the coordination chain exhibits controllable fluorescence-switching behavior.

elements.content: Cyclophanes have attracted special attention owing to their intriguing stereochemistry and optical properties resulting from intramolecular interactions between the π-electron systems of two aromatic rings. Among these bridged aromatic compounds, syn-cyclophanes are more attractive because the face-to-face arranged aromatic nuclei result in more intense electronic interactions than those of their anti conformers. As a result, syn-cyclophanes have provided intramolecular excimer fluorescence in solution and in the solid state. However, due to the inherently high strain in syn-cyclophanes, such compounds are difficult or even impossible to obtain through traditional solution-based reactions. Solid-state photochemical reactions of certain divinylbenzene derivatives enhance the yield and selectivity of syn-cyclophane products. The divinylbenzene derivatives are conjugated and exhibit good fluorescence. If the syn-cyclophanes and divinylbenzene derivatives can be transformed reversibly in a confined medium, then this medium can be used as a promising smart material for the fabrication of photoswitches or rewritable optical data storage devices.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Cyclophanes have attracted special attention owing to their intriguing stereochemistry and optical properties resulting from intramolecular interactions between the π-electron systems of two aromatic rings. Among these bridged aromatic compounds, syn-cyclophanes are more attractive because the face-to-face arranged aromatic nuclei result in more intense electronic interactions than those of their anti conformers. As a result, syn-cyclophanes have provided intramolecular excimer fluorescence in solution and in the solid state. However, due to the inherently high strain in syn-cyclophanes, such compounds are difficult or even impossible to obtain through traditional solution-based reactions. Solid-state photochemical reactions of certain divinylbenzene derivatives enhance the yield and selectivity of syn-cyclophane products. The divinylbenzene derivatives are conjugated and exhibit good fluorescence. If the syn-cyclophanes and divinylbenzene derivatives can be transformed reversibly in a confined medium, then this medium can be used as a promising smart material for the fabrication of photoswitches or rewritable optical data storage devices.

elements.content: Considering the potential media, crystalline coordination polymers would be ideal candidates owing to their controllable structures and high stabilities. To date, the most precise method to characterize the structural transformations of coordination polymers is single-crystal X-ray diffraction. In this respect, in situ observation of reactions within coordination polymer frameworks through single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformation is particularly important to understand structure–property relationships with the ultimate aim of creating new crystalline functional materials. Unfortunately, the single-crystal character of a coordination polymer is usually lost during multistep transformations because the crystal cannot endure the internal strains induced by significant atom movements. Most reported multistep SCSC transformations involve adsorption and desorption processes. As the forming and breaking of covalent bonds should resist more strain than adsorption and desorption, sequential or reversible SCSC organic reactions are extremely rare.

Unfortunately, the single-crystal character of a coordination polymer is usually lost during multistep transformations because the crystal cannot endure the internal strains induced by significant atom movements. Most reported multistep SCSC transformations involve adsorption and desorption processes. As the forming and breaking of covalent bonds should resist more strain than adsorption and desorption, sequential or reversible SCSC organic reactions are extremely rare.

elements.content: As a derivative of divinylbenzene, each pair of 1,3-bis­[2-(4-pyridyl)­ethenyl]­benzene (1,3-bpeb) moieties may be arranged in a photoreactive face-to-face manner with modification of the appropriate intermolecular interactions. Upon long-wave UV irradiation, the face-to-face aligned 1,3-bpeb molecules dimerize to syn-tetrakis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2,9,10-diethano­[2.2]­metacyclophane (syn-tpmcp) (). It is possible to regenerate 1,3-bpeb from syn-tpmcp () since the cyclobutane groups in organic compounds can be cleaved with short-wave UV light. When a powdered sample of 1,3-bpeb was exposed to UV irradiation for 1 day using a 200 W high-pressure mercury lamp (λ = 365 nm), the solid was verified to be photoinert by 1H NMR spectroscopy (Figure S1). Intermolecular interactions should be utilized to enhance the photoreactivity of 1,3-bpeb. Considering the potential coordination environments of common metal ions, Cd­(NO3)2 and suitable carboxylic acids may be promising candidates to react with 1,3-bpeb for this study. This is because the combination of Cd ions and carboxylate anions commonly results in the generation of dinuclear Cd-carboxylate units which can clip each pair of adjacent 1,3-bpeb molecules within relatively short distances for photodimerization reactions. Hydrothermal reactions between Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O with 1,3-bpeb, 4-chlorobenzoic acid (4-CBA), or 4-fluorobenzoic acid (4-FBA) in NaOH aqueous solution resulted in the formation of two one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymers [Cd2(1,3-bpeb)2­(4-CBA)4] n (1) and {[Cd2(1,3-bpeb)2­(4-FBA)4]·H2O} n (3). We anticipated that the two stable coordination polymers could be used for the investigation of reversible SCSC transformations based on the photocontrollable reaction between 1,3-bpeb and syn-tpmcp. Described below are their synthesis, structural characterization, photochemical transformations, and fluorescence-switching behaviors.

elements.content: The ligand 1,3-bpeb was prepared as reported previously. Other reagents and solvents were purchased from TCI Co., Ltd., and Sigma-Aldrich Co. All chemicals were used without any further purification. Infrared spectra (KBr pellets) were obtained in the 4000–400 cm–1 range using a Nicolet Avatar 360 FTIR spectrophotometer. The elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on an EA1110 CHNS elemental analyzer. Melting points were measured with a YCYQ WRX-4 micro melting point apparatus without correction. PXRD patterns were obtained using a PANalytical X’Pert PRO MPD system (PW3040/60). Thermal analyses were performed with a PerkinElmer TGA-7 thermogravimetric analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C/min and a flow rate of 100 cm3/min (N2). 1H NMR spectra were recorded at ambient temperature on a Bruker ADVANCE III (400 MHz) spectrometer. The 1H NMR chemical shifts of all compounds were referenced to the d 6-DMSO solvent signal. Although the original 1D coordination polymers that were dissolved in DMSO may be decomposed into individual building blocks, these building blocks did not interfere with the determination of the organic ligands in the coordination polymers by 1H NMR. Cross-polarization magic angle spinning (CPMAS) 13C NMR spectra were recorded at a resonance frequency of 101.6 MHz on a BRUKER ADVANCE DSX 400 MHz spectrometer at ambient temperature. High-resolution mass spectra (HRMS) were obtained by electrospray ionization (ESI). UV–vis absorption spectra were obtained with a Shimadzu UV-3600 spectrophotometer. The confocal fluorescence microscopy images were taken with an Olympus FluoView FV 1000 confocal laser-scanning microscope. The fluorescence spectra were acquired on an Edinburgh Instruments FLS920 fluorescence spectrophotometer with powdered samples. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken on a Hitachi S-4700 field emission scanning electron microscope.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

The ligand 1,3-bpeb was prepared as reported previously. Other reagents and solvents were purchased from TCI Co., Ltd., and Sigma-Aldrich Co. All chemicals were used without any further purification. Infrared spectra (KBr pellets) were obtained in the 4000-400 cm-1 range using a Nicolet Avatar 360 FTIR spectrophotometer. The elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on an EA1110 CHNS elemental analyzer. Melting points were measured with a YCYQ WRX-4 micro melting point apparatus without correction. PXRD patterns were obtained using a PANalytical X'Pert PRO MPD system (PW3040/60). Thermal analyses were performed with a PerkinElmer TGA-7 thermogravimetric analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C/min and a flow rate of 100 cm3/min (N2). 1H NMR spectra were recorded at ambient temperature on a Bruker ADVANCE III (400 MHz) spectrometer. The 1H NMR chemical shifts of all compounds were referenced to the d 6-DMSO solvent signal. Although the original 1D coordination polymers that were dissolved in DMSO may be decomposed into individual building blocks, these building blocks did not interfere with the determination of the organic ligands in the coordination polymers by 1H NMR. Cross-polarization magic angle spinning (CPMAS) 13C NMR spectra were recorded at a resonance frequency of 101.6 MHz on a BRUKER ADVANCE DSX 400 MHz spectrometer at ambient temperature. High-resolution mass spectra (HRMS) were obtained by electrospray ionization (ESI). UV-vis absorption spectra were obtained with a Shimadzu UV-3600 spectrophotometer. The confocal fluorescence microscopy images were taken with an Olympus FluoView FV 1000 confocal laser-scanning microscope. The fluorescence spectra were acquired on an Edinburgh Instruments FLS920 fluorescence spectrophotometer with powdered samples. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken on a Hitachi S-4700 field emission scanning electron microscope.

elements.content: To a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave was loaded Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (154 mg, 0.5 mmol), 1,3-bpeb (142 mg, 0.5 mmol), 4-chlorobenzoic acid (157 mg, 1.0 mmol), NaOH solution (1.0 mol L–1, 1.0 mL), and H2O (25 mL). The autoclave was sealed and heated in an oven at 150 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C h–1 to form light yellow crystals of 1, which were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with EtOH and Et2O, and dried in air. Yield: 308 mg (87% yield based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C68H48Cd2­Cl4N4O8: C, 57.69; H, 3.42; N, 3.96. Found: C, 57.86; H, 3.55; N, 4.08. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3422m, 1608s, 1541s, 1503w, 1403s, 1280w, 1222m, 1169m, 1015m, 958s, 853m, 812s, 688m, 537s, 410w. Mp 300–301 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 298 K): δ 8.60 (s, 8H), 7.96 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 10H), 7.61 (t, J = 16.4, 8.0 Hz, 16H), 7.47 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 10H), 7.35 (d, J = 16.4 Hz, 4H).

elements.content: A mixture of Na2Y·2H2O (Y = ethylene diamine tetraacetate) (560 mg, 1.50 mmol), 1a (283 mg, 0.20 mmol), NaOH solution (1.0 mol L–1, 3.0 mL), H2O (20 mL), and CH2Cl2 (30 mL) was placed in a 100 mL flask and stirred for 12 h. The organic phase was separated from the mixture, and the aqueous layers were extracted with CH2Cl2 (2 × 30 mL). The combined organic phase was concentrated to dryness in vacuo to give syn-tpmcp as a white powder. Yield: 94 mg (83% based on 1a). Anal. Calcd for C40H32N4: C, 84.48; H, 5.67; N, 9.85. elements.content: Single crystals of 1, 2, 3, and 4 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained directly from the above preparations. All measurements were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) by using the Φ/ω scan technique. Absorption correction was based on symmetry equivalent reflections using the SADABS program. All crystal structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods with the SHELXL-2014 program. Structure 2 was found to contain pockets of diffuse electron density which were unable to be sensibly modeled, and as such, its contribution to the diffraction data was accounted for with the SQUEEZE routine within PLATON, with assignment of encapsulated solvent toluene molecules made on the basis of calculated electron count. The calculations indicate the presence of 303 e– per unit cell or approximately 152 electrons per syn-tpmcp molecule. Comparison with microanalysis results suggests three toluene molecules per syn-tpmcp molecule. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The H atoms of the water molecules in 2, 3, and 4 were located from the Fourier map and included in the final refinement by use of geometrical restraints with the O–H distances being fixed at 0.85 Å and U iso(H) equivalent to 1.5 times U eq(O). All other H atoms were introduced at the calculated positions and included in the structure-factor calculations. A summary of the key crystallographic data for 1, 2, 3, and 4 is provided in .

All measurements were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) by using the Φ/ω scan technique. Absorption correction was based on symmetry equivalent reflections using the SADABS program. All crystal structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods with the SHELXL-2014 program. The calculations indicate the presence of 303 e- per unit cell or approximately 152 electrons per syn-tpmcp molecule. The H atoms of the water molecules in 2, 3, and 4 were located from the Fourier map and included in the final refinement by use of geometrical restraints with the O-H distances being fixed at 0.85 Å and U iso(H) equivalent to 1.5 times U eq(O). All other H atoms were introduced at the calculated positions and included in the structure-factor calculations. A summary of the key crystallographic data for 1, 2, 3, and 4 is provided in .

Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. There are two crystallographically independent Cd ions in 1. Each pair of Cd ions is anchored by four 4-CBA anions to form one [Cd2(4-CBA)4] unit. The adjacent dinuclear [Cd2(4-CBA)4] units are bridged by pairs of 1,3-bpeb linkers to generate a zigzag chain of [Cd2(1,3-bpeb)2­(4-CBA)4] n (). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) confirms the phase purity of 1 (Figure S2). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) revealed that 1 has no weight loss up to 302 °C (Figure S3). In 1, one pair of olefinic bonds in each set of the neighboring 1,3-bpeb molecules is aligned to be parallel with a centroid separation of 3.98 Å (black striped connections in ) while the other pair of olefinic bonds is arranged in a crisscross fashion with a distance of 4.01 Å (pink striped connections in ). According to Schmidt’s topochemical criteria for a photodimerization reaction, it seems that only one pair of parallel olefinic bonds in each set of adjacent 1,3-bpeb molecules can undergo a photodimerization reaction. To verify the photoreactivity of 1, single crystals of 1 were subjected to UV irradiation using a 200 W high-pressure mercury lamp (λ = 365 nm) for a period of 8 h resulting in a sample of 1a. The PXRD pattern of 1a is different from that of 1, indicating that a photoreaction occurred (Figure S2). The 1H NMR spectrum of 1a shows complete disappearance of the signal for the olefinic protons at 7.61 and 7.35 ppm and the appearance of a characteristic signal at 5.02–4.53 ppm derived from cyclobutane protons, suggesting that all olefinic bonds in 1 are dimerized into cyclobutane (Figure S4). Cross-polarization magic angle spinning (CPMAS) 13C NMR spectrum of 1a exhibits the disappearance of the typical signals for an olefin at 131.18 and 121.76 ppm and the emergence of a characteristic peak for cyclobutane at 46.22 ppm, confirming the conversion from 1 to 1a (Figure S5). Attempts to achieve SCSC transformation from 1 to 1a failed due to the tendency for the single crystals to crack upon irradiation by UV light.

elements.content: To determine the structure of the organic photoproduct, a white powder of syn-tpmcp was isolated through extraction from 1a using CH2Cl2 and Na2Y (Y = ethylene diamine tetraacetate) aqueous solution. Dissolving syn-tpmcp in toluene/H2O followed by slow evaporation of the solvents afforded crystals of 2. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction confirmed the formation of syn-tpmcp (). 1H NMR verified the purity of the obtained photoproduct syn-tpmcp (Figure S4). The conversion of 1,3-bpeb to syn-tpmcp may be caused by a pedal-like motion of one olefinic bond in each pair of crisscross arranged olefinic bonds. Apart from a peak at m/z 569.2702 that corresponded to the molecular ion of [syn-tpmcp + H]+, high-resolution mass spectroscopy (HRMS) of syn-tpmcp also showed an obvious peak related to [1,3-bpeb + H]+ at m/z 285.1387 (Figure S6), suggesting that syn-tpmcp may undergo a reverse reaction to give 1,3-bpeb. Such a phenomenon stimulated us to explore the potential reversible SCSC transformation between 1,3-bpeb and syn-tpmcp in other coordination polymers.

elements.content: The poor stability of single crystals of 1 upon UV irradiation may be owed to the intense atomic vibration that was induced by pedal-like motion. If two pairs of olefinic bonds in each pair of adjacent 1,3-bpeb molecules in 1 are all aligned parallel, the intensity of atomic movements can be relieved in a photocycloaddition process and an SCSC transformation may be achieved. Considering the steric effects and different electron withdrawing ability of fluorine and chlorine atoms in the corresponding 4-halogenated benzoic acids, we employed 4-fluorobenzoic acid to replace 4-chlorobenzoic acid and carried out a similar reaction. Light yellow crystals of {[Cd2(1,3-bpeb)2(4-FBA)4]·H2O} n (3) were isolated. TGA revealed that 3 is stable up to 310 °C (Figure S3). Compound 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2/c (). Similar to 1, 3 is also a zigzag chain (a). In 3, each pair of 1,3-bpeb molecules is arranged in a face-to-face mode and all 1,3-bpeb molecules adopt the same conformation. As a result, all neighboring olefinic bonds in 3 are aligned to be parallel. The centroid to centroid distance between each pair of adjacent olefinic bonds is 3.64 Å (striped connections in a). Such an alignment indicates that these pairs are favorable for a photodimerization reaction.

elements.content: UV light irradiation over single crystals of 3 using a 200 W high-pressure mercury lamp (λ = 365 nm) for 6 h led to the formation of syn-tpmcp (b). This photodimerization did occur in an SCSC fashion, which afforded single crystals of {[Cd2(syn-tpmcp)­(4-FBA)4]·H2O} n (4). To our surprise, 4 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ () as opposed to the monoclinic space group P2/c of 3. During the reaction process, the cell volume was contracted from 3011 Å3 (3) to 2917 Å3 (4), and all of the atoms in the coordination chain underwent considerable movement. For example, owing to the intense strains of the newly formed syn-tpmcp ligands, even the separation between two heavy Cd atoms within a Cd2(4-FBA)4 unit is increased from 3.94 Å in 3 to 4.10 Å in 4. The Cd–O and Cd–N bond lengths are also different in 3 and 4 (Table S1). The PXRD pattern indicates that the single crystal used in the structure determination was representative of the bulk sample (Figure S2). 1H NMR (Figure S4) and 13C CPMAS spectroscopy () further confirmed the complete transformation from 3 to 4. Some interesting SCSC transformations of photoreactive coordination chains have been reported previously. In those chains, photodimerization of the mono-olefin trans-1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene led to the formation of the dimeric species 1,2,3,4-tetrakis­(4-pyridyl)­cyclobutane. To date, the SCSC transformation from divinylbenzene to cyclophane in a coordination chain has not been investigated.

elements.content: Encouraged by the successful SCSC transformation from 3 to 4, we attempted to investigate whether the reverse reaction from 4 to 3 can be achieved via irradiation with short-wave UV light. After exposure under a low-pressure (50 W) mercury lamp (λ = 254 nm) for 10 h, the transparency and single-crystal nature of 4 were retained. The PXRD pattern of this reirradiated sample is not well matched with that of 4, but is similar to that of 3 (Figure S2). The disappearance of the signals at 5.01–4.53 ppm for cyclobutane protons and the emergence of the signals at 7.61 and 7.35 ppm for olefinic protons in 1H NMR spectrum also verified the completion of the reaction from syn-tpmcp to 1,3-bpeb (Figure S4). The 13C CPMAS NMR spectra showed conspicuous chemical shifts from 46.75 ppm (cyclobutane) to 132.05 and 120.05 ppm (olefin), suggesting the reversible transformation from the dimer syn-tpmcp to the monomer 1,3-bpeb in the coordination chain ().

elements.content: The solid-state optical absorbance of 4 and regenerated 3 were investigated using UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra at ambient temperature (). The absorption (α/S) data were calculated from the reflectance by the Kubelka–Munk method: α/S = (1 – R)2/2R, where α is the absorption, S is the scattering coefficient, and R is the reflectance at a given wavelength. These distinct absorptions confirmed the complete reversibility of the conversion between 3 and 4. Single-crystal X-ray crystallography indicated that the structure of this reirradiated product is the same as that of 3. This evidence demonstrated that the reversible conversion between 3 and 4 had been achieved in an SCSC fashion (). To our knowledge, this is the first example of a reversible SCSC transformation that involves the dimerization and dedimerization of a syn-[2,2]­metacyclophane.

elements.content: Illumination over the bulk powdered crystalline samples of 3 and 4 at ambient temperature with weak UV light revealed that these two compounds display prominently different fluorescence emissions. Such an observation was further corroborated by laser-scanning confocal fluorescence microscopy, which exhibited a consistent difference in fluorescence between 3 and 4. As shown in , both single-crystal and powdered crystalline samples of 3 emit green fluorescence, suggesting that the emissions are propagated from the bulk. In situ UV irradiation of 3 with 365 nm UV light for 6 h resulted in blue fluorescence emission of both single-crystal and powdered crystalline samples. For each image, a corresponding bandpass filter was set to separate the light from the fluorescence of each sample. The range of the bandpass filter was from 443 to 561 nm. The fluorescence may be presumably influenced by the presence of either 1,3-bpeb or syn-tpmcp due to their different conjugation, localization of π electrons, and intramolecular electronic interactions.

elements.content: The solid-state fluorescence emission maximum of a powder sample of 3 was observed at 522 nm (λex = 380 nm) by using a fluorescence spectrometer. Upon the same excitation, 4 exhibited an emission band at 465 nm. The emission bands for 3 and 4 are probably ascribed to a mixture characteristic of intraligand and ligand-to-ligand charge-transfer (LLCT) transitions, due to the close similarity of the excitation and emission wavelengths of 1,3-bpeb (λex = 378 nm, λem = 510 nm) and syn-tpmcp (λex = 373 nm, λem = 456 nm) (a). Quantum yield measurements were performed using the absolute method on an FLS920 from Edinburgh Instruments equipped with a BaSO4-coated integrating sphere, a 450W Xe900 xenon lamp, and a R928P PMT detector. Samples 3 and 4 were measured at an excitation wavelength of 380 nm. The absolute quantum yields were calculated by comparing the integral of emission and the absorption of excitation light, with a sensitivity correction for the detector. The photoluminescence quantum yield at room temperature is 10.3% with the lifetime of 2.51 ns for 3. For 4, its fluorescence quantum yield is 4.1%, and its emission decay lifetime is 1.22 ns. For potential utility, a high fatigue resistance is indispensable to achieve the repeated “recording” and “erasing” of optical information. To this end, the photocontrollable dimerization and dedimerization reversibility cycle experiments for the crystalline powder sample of 3 were carried out. The fluorescence at 465 and 522 nm was monitored for each cycle. After 10 cycles, the attenuation of emission intensity of the sample at characteristic fluorescence is negligible (b). These results indicate that 3 is a promising smart material in fluorescence switching and rewritable optical recording devices.

elements.content: For optical recording applications, the materials are usually prepared as tiny particles or thin films. Compared with the thickness of small particles or thin films, the single crystals are relatively thick. Owing to the optical absorbance and reflection of single crystals, more time should be devoted to achieve the complete photochemical conversion. When the crystals of 3 were ground and further fragmented by using ultrasound, tiny particles of 3 could be obtained (). As confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy (Figure S7), the photodimerization and dephotodimerization reactions of such tiny particles could be accomplished within 2 min. The fast responses provide more potential for the practical applications.

elements.content: In the work reported herein, we have demonstrated for the first time a reversible SCSC transformation of one 1D coordination polymer 3 into the other 1D coordination polymer 4 accompanied by the photocontrollable dimerization and dedimerization of a syn-[2.2]­metacyclophane. Furthermore, controllable fluorescence changes of the coordination polymers based on the reversible SCSC transformation were observed. It is anticipated that [2.2]­cyclophane chemistry may be applied to design more intelligent materials to prepare photoswitches, image recording, and optical data storage devices. Studies like these are currently underway in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In the work reported herein, we have demonstrated for the first time a reversible SCSC transformation of one 1D coordination polymer 3 into the other 1D coordination polymer 4 accompanied by the photocontrollable dimerization and dedimerization of a syn-[2.2]metacyclophane. Furthermore, controllable fluorescence changes of the coordination polymers based on the reversible SCSC transformation were observed. It is anticipated that [2.2]cyclophane chemistry may be applied to design more intelligent materials to prepare photoswitches, image recording, and optical data storage devices. Studies like these are currently underway in our laboratory.

To a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave was loaded Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (154 mg, 0.5 mmol), 1,3-bpeb (142 mg, 0.5 mmol), 4-chlorobenzoic acid (157 mg, 1.0 mmol), NaOH solution (1.0 mol L–1, 1.0 mL), and H2O (25 mL). The autoclave was sealed and heated in an oven at 150 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C h–1 to form light yellow crystals of 1, which were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with EtOH and Et2O, and dried in air. Yield: 308 mg (87% yield based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C68H48Cd2­Cl4N4O8: C, 57.69; H, 3.42; N, 3.96. Found: C, 57.86; H, 3.55; N, 4.08. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3422m, 1608s, 1541s, 1503w, 1403s, 1280w, 1222m, 1169m, 1015m, 958s, 853m, 812s, 688m, 537s, 410w. Mp 300–301 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 298 K): δ 8.60 (s, 8H), 7.96 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 10H), 7.61 (t, J = 16.4, 8.0 Hz, 16H), 7.47 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 10H), 7.35 (d, J = 16.4 Hz, 4H).

Preparation of [Cd<sub>2</sub>(<italic>syn</italic>-tpmcp)­(4-CBA)<sub>4</sub>]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1a</bold>)

Single crystals of 1 were irradiated by a high-pressure Hg lamp (λ = 365 nm, 200 W) for 8 h to form light yellow cracked crystals of 1a in 100% yield based on 1. Anal. Calcd for C68H48­Cd2Cl4N4O8: C, 57.69; H, 3.42; N, 3.96. Found: C, 57.75; H, 3.54; N, 3.85. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3420m, 1613s, 1541s, 1504w, 1403s, 1281w, 1223m, 1140m, 1014m, 854m, 821s, 689m, 537s, 413w. Mp 256–258 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 298 K): δ 8.41 (s, 8H), 7.96 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 8H), 7.53 (m, 10H), 7.32 (d, J = 18.4 Hz, 8H), 6.76–6.54 (m, 6H), 5.02–4.53 (m, 8H).

Preparation of <italic>syn</italic>-tpmcp·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of Na2Y·2H2O (Y = ethylene diamine tetraacetate) (560 mg, 1.50 mmol), 1a (283 mg, 0.20 mmol), NaOH solution (1.0 mol L–1, 3.0 mL), H2O (20 mL), and CH2Cl2 (30 mL) was placed in a 100 mL flask and stirred for 12 h. The organic phase was separated from the mixture, and the aqueous layers were extracted with CH2Cl2 (2 × 30 mL). The combined organic phase was concentrated to dryness in vacuo to give syn-tpmcp as a white powder. Yield: 94 mg (83% based on 1a). Anal. Calcd for C40H32N4: C, 84.48; H, 5.67; N, 9.85. Found: C, 84.33; H, 5.78; N, 9.78. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3391m, 1600s, 1555m, 1487w, 1416s, 1221m, 1166m, 999m, 938s, 838m, 803s, 690m, 543s, 418w. Mp 143–144 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 298 K): δ 8.38 (d, J = 4.4 Hz, 8H), 7.28 (dd, J = 21.2, 5.2 Hz, 8H), 6.90–6.58 (m, 8H), 5.00–4.48 (m, 8H). HRMS (ESI, m/z) Calcd for C40H32N4 [M + H]+: 569.2700. Found: 569.2702. Slow evaporation of a solution of the white powder of syn-tpmcp in toluene/water afforded colorless single crystals of 2.

Preparation of {[Cd<sub>2</sub>(1,3-bpeb)<sub>2</sub>­(4-FBA)<sub>4</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Light yellow crystals of 3 were prepared by a route analogous to that used for the isolation of 1, starting from Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (154 mg, 0.5 mmol), 1,3-bpeb (142 mg, 0.5 mmol), 4-fluorobenzoic acid (140 mg, 1.0 mmol), NaOH solution (1.0 mol L–1, 1.0 mL), and H2O (25 mL) at 150 °C for 2 days. Yield: 301 mg (88% yield based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C68H50Cd2­F4N4O9: C, 59.70; H, 3.68; N, 4.10. Found: C, 59.91; H, 3.59; N, 4.21. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3409m, 1608s, 1544s, 1504w, 1399s, 1295w, 1221m, 1150m, 1016m, 969s, 862m, 813s, 690m, 546s, 408w. Mp 309–310 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 298 K): δ 8.61 (s, 8H), 8.01 (dd, J = 14.0, 7.2 Hz, 10H), 7.62 (t, J = 16.8, 7.2 Hz, 16H), 7.47 (t, J = 7.6, 7.6 Hz, 2H), 7.35 (d, J = 16.4 Hz, 4H), 7.22 (t, J = 8.8, 8.4 Hz, 8H).

Preparation of {[Cd<sub>2</sub>(<italic>syn</italic>-tpmcp)­(4-FBA)<sub>4</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

Single crystals of 3 were irradiated by a high-pressure Hg lamp (λ = 365 nm, 200 W) for 6 h to afford light yellow crystals of 4 in 100% yield based on 3. Anal. Calcd for C68H50Cd2­F4N4O9: C, 59.70; H, 3.68; N, 4.10. Found: C, 59.87; H, 3.76; N, 4.24. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3403m, 1610s, 1545s, 1406s, 1298w, 1223m, 1151m, 1016m, 968s, 862m, 783s, 691m, 539s, 411w. Mp 269–270 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 298 K): δ 8.42 (s, 8H), 8.01 (t, J = 7.2, 6.4 Hz, 8H), 7.34–7.20 (m, 18H), 6.76–6.54 (m, 6H), 5.01–4.53 (m, 8H).
